Comments_List: This was a broad survey course so I feel like we learned a little about a lot.
More comprehensive knowledge of systems in primates and humans.
I learned more about brain strucutrs, anatomy, and functions based on circuitry established in research

This course provided a detailed examinations of sensory, motor, and cognitive function in connections to human disorder. I was able to become exposed to various fundamental papers and all the research that is currently being conducted at Yale. I believe this class improved my critical thinking skills.
More profound understanding of systems neuroscience, specifically in understanding the experiments that led our knowledge about cortical circuits

Strengths: It was great having different lecturers for various topics. 

Weaknesses: Often the speakers did not coordinate, so there was overlapping or missing material. Additionally, some of the lectures felt like the material was being spoon fed as opposed to going over the studies that led to the conclusions.

Strengths: Lectures from many different faculty members
Weaknesses: Hard to stay engaged with a purely lecture format; lack of feedback on exam

Some lectures were very moleculer while others were more system based. I think they should al be systems based
We go into sensotry system a lot in fall, so there I feel like it is not a very necessary lecture in spring

Strengths: Diverse set of lecturers, supplementary reading material
Weaknesses: Very "vision-heavy" in the beginning

Strengths: great faculty lecturers, great breadth of topics, a good level of depth in those topics
Weaknesses: lack of consistency and continuity between knowledge covered by lecturers
No. Especially if the student had already taken neurobiology, there was very little to be gained from this course.
Yes, this class gives you an overview of systems (particularly higher level cortical systems in primate and humans) that are not covered in other neuro systems classes.
Yes. This class is perfect for those who are interested in clinical neuroscience research. It was also great to review concepts that we went over in the previous semester.
Yes, if that student had an interest in systems neuroscience
